Award.AwardTitle: Every Day, Every Child: A Partnership for Research with Elementary Math and Science Instructional Specialists

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This exploratory project is studying the use of mathematics and science specialist teachers in elementary schools. The first four studies are in six school districts in Washington State. They are characterizing and categorizing the specialists, investigating the content knowledge, preparation and needs of these teachers, determining their instructional effectiveness, and determining their impact on student learning and attitudes towards mathematics and science. The project is recruiting 25 specialists in math and 15 in science and comparing them with equal numbers of matched non-specialist teachers. The fifth study is conducting a survey of state educational agencies to determine the types of specialist teaching models being used and how they are funded. The project is directed by Western Washington University in partnership with the Mathematics Education Collaboration.

The project is creating interview protocols for teachers and administrators, and utilizing Learning Math for Teaching (University of Michigan) and Assessing Teacher Learning About Science Teaching (ATLAST-Horizon Research). Classroom observations are being conducted using the Reformed Teaching Observational Protocol (RTOP-Arizona State University). Student measures include the Washington State Measures of Student Progress in math and science, an instrument to be created using items released by the National Assessment of Educational Progress (NAEP), the Attitudes Towards Math Inventory, and the Modified Attitudes Towards Science Inventory.

Project research results are being disseminated in mathematics and science educational journals and conference presentations and are being posted on the project website. Findings are be shared with the Educational Service Districts in Washington State and other State agencies, as well as the National Educational Association and the American Federation of Teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Every Day Every Child was an exploratory research project designed to understand and categorize elementary content specialist (ECS) models in mathematics and science; investigate the content knowledge, preparation and needs of teachers in these roles; determine the instructional effectiveness of ECS teachers; determine the impact of ECS teachers on student learning and attitudes towards mathematics and science; and investigate the prevalence of models in use throughout the United States.

The project’s analysis of ECS models included three broad categories: within-grade team teaching, across-grade team teaching, and science as a special. The team teaching categories were further parsed and described as serving 2-3 classes of students, with teachers specializing in 1-3 content areas. The science as a special category included teachers who serviced elementary students in science much as specialist teachers such as music, physical education, and library teachers. A number of affordances and constraints were identified based on teacher interviews and surveys, in comparison to self-contained elementary teachers. Affordances included focus, planning time, professional development focus, and instructional time (science only). Challenges included collaboration, number of students, and flexibility. There were no significant differences in ECS and self-contained teachers’ reported transition times or ability to meet the academic, social, and emotional needs of the students.

ECS teachers in mathematics scored higher (on average) than their self-contained matches on the three subtests of mathematics content assessments. However, none of these differences were statistically significant. A comparison of instructional quality for ECS teachers in mathematics and their self-contained matches also indicated there were no significant differences. The scores for both groups were wide-ranging, indicating that there is deficient, mediocre, and exemplary instruction happening in both specialist and self-contained classrooms.

ECS teachers in science scored higher (on average) than their self-contained matches on the four subtests of science content assessments. These differences were statistically significant for three of the four subtests: Astronomy/Space Science, Earth Science, and Physical Science. A comparison of instructional quality for ECS teachers in science and their self-contained matches revealed statistically significant differences in two areas (using evidence to make claims and sense making) and meaningful effect sizes in an additional three areas (total score, targeted idea, and classroom culture).

Comparisons of students’ attitudes towards mathematics and science indicated no significant differences between students of ECS teachers and students in self-contained settings, either overall or along factors. Changes in state assessments and incomplete data sets made a comparison of students’ achievement in these subject areas inappropriate.

The national survey of elementary school principals indicated that mathematics and/or science specialization occurs in approximately 55% of elementary schools nationwide. Specialization in mathematics is slightly higher than science, and specialization is more likely to occur in grades 3-5 than the primary grades. In addition, principals in schools where specialization was not occurring did not indicate compelling reasons not to specialize.

Findings from the multiple studies of this exploratory project are reported in three publications, with an additional two publications under review. Overall, we expect that the findings reported from this study will impact the field by providing evidence that enthusiasm for the subject is not enough to ensure quality instruction. Instead, professional development must support mathematics and science specialists so that more students are receiving better instruction. Specialization significantly reduces the number of teachers that would need professional development support, so implementing the models we have investigated and providing support for quality instruction may be a cost-effective way for elementary schools to improve mathematics and science instruction, and ultimately, students’ learning.
